SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take the opportunity to speak on the report from the Department of Social Security entitled Data-matching Program. I particularly want to ensure that the social security aspects of the report do not pass without comment. Data matching has been an important issue over a long period. It is important not to lose sight of the assurances that were given by the government at the time data matching was developing. It was the view of the parliament that data matching, because of its intrusive nature, ought not to proceed without question.

PARA.TAB: I was interested to read again an Australian Labor Party policy speech which was made in 1984. It was made after some changes had been made in the area of assets and income testing and the government wanted to reassure people about the likely impact of its new assets test. One ought not to forget these things and it is interesting to look back at some of the government's comments. The government gave commitments, firstly, that people would never see social security inspectors in their homes, and, secondly, that information gathered for the purposes of the assets test would not be used for any other revenue purpose. Interestingly enough, the third commitment was that the assets test will not be made more stringent by this government.

In relation to the second of those assurances that the government gave, data matching is the basis upon which information is provided for the assets test. It also provides all the government's information for the purposes of testing eligibility and for saving revenue in relation to Social Security and to other government departments. Of course, information is provided under this legislation to other agencies for their purposes.

The third issue which was adverted to was that the assets test would not be made more stringent. I do not know what the government is intending to do in the context of the forthcoming budget but it is interesting that one of the major issues relating to stringency was the extent to which unrealised capital gains on shares and managed investments were treated as income for the purposes of the income test. If that did not mean that the tests were not given greater stringency, I do not know what was.

Notwithstanding the assurances that were given, the government moved rigorously and enthusiastically into this area of data matching. It gave certain assurances as to what it thought would result from the implementation of data matching. It predicted that the data-matching program would result in something of the order of $300 million in savings. That was in 1992-93. Over time, the department downgraded its savings estimates. It did so in Senate estimates to a $70 million figure. At a later point, when the matter was the subject of a more detailed comprehensive review by the Auditor-General in the efficiency audit, Audit report No. 7 1993-94, that was downgraded even further to a saving of $17.3 million in that period.

It is also interesting to go back and look at what was being said. The parliament has been saying that data matching was intrusive; there needed to be very significant cost benefit to proceed with a program that was going to be intrusive and it was necessary to be able to demonstrate that. Of course, the demonstration was to be occasioned by detailed and comprehensive reports and the role of the Auditor-General was crucial in relation to that.

A sunset clause was also placed in the legislation, a clause that the government keeps on wanting to take out and that the opposition in its usual cooperative way has extended to give the government an opportunity to come up with a proper justification for the data-matching program implementation and to demonstrate its effectiveness.

So it is important in the context of looking at the paper that we have before us today to review what the Auditor-General had to say, particularly in relation to benefits. On page 11 of the report's summary—and I think it is easier to understand it in that context—the Auditor-General made this point:

SPEECH.PARA: The original estimate supporting the introduction of the Data-Matching Program suggested full-year savings of $300m per annum. The estimate did not include savings arising through partial downward variations in fortnightly rates or recovery of overpayments. These original saving estimates were not achieved, and were revised downwards in October 1992, and again this year.
And the report went on to make the point that I made earlier:
The downward variations in payments, which were the basis of the original estimates, represent only $17m of the 1992-93 savings of $75m (as at the date of the audit).
The ANAO considers that the value of overpayments is likely to reduce in future years. As a consequence DSS has reduced the value of overpayment amounts since projected savings estimates.

It talked about the `deterrent effect' because the department argued that if you proceed with data matching, while the savings may not be so significant, it would have a deterrent effect, which would in fact save money. The Auditor-General had some comments to make about that:

At the time of the audit, there had been no effective estimates of the deterrent effect of the DMP. Whilst recognising the difficulties in isolating and quantifying the deterrent effect due to the DMP (and TFN collection), the ANAO considers that a more considered evaluation of this effect is necessary both for assessing program savings and the costs/ benefits of the program.
The report indicated that:
The Department will be presenting available evidence in its October 1993 Progress Report.
And it made some comments on program performance, some comparisons:

Program performance is variable when examined across a spectrum of baselines. It is effective in its identification of overpayments, reflecting benefits which have been incorrectly paid for some time. The program is also effective in identifying incorrect family payments not detected by other DSS review methods. This reinforces the view that the program provides a valuable vehicle for review of client circumstances that would not otherwise be as readily detected.
But it goes on:
However, the data-matching program outcomes have fallen well short of DSS

predictions. Current circumstances in the client population together with changes in DSS control and review activities may have contributed to the shortfall in achieving predicted outcomes for the program. These considerations, as well at the unquantified deterrent effect, make conclusions about the overall cost effectiveness of the program difficult, and reinforce the need for a more comprehensive cost/benefit analysis. They also highlight the scope for more efficiency to be pursued in Data-matching work.

I think it is important to recognise the nature of those comments because the department was being very severely criticised by the Auditor-General. It was not satisfied that there had been an effective cost-benefit analysis.

PARA.TAB: Now we have the department's report on data matching, which attempts to deal with these matters, and I simply want to make some comments on that. The first concerns the fraud control strategy. The department, on page 5, is saying that data matching is now not an important end in itself. It now puts the first point of emphasis on encouraging voluntary compliance. So we are moving away from the idea that one can justify the argument that there are effective savings resulting from data matching, because the evidence is that that has not been achieved, to the more esoteric view that one can justify it because we are getting additional compliance that we would not otherwise have got, because people are more afraid that they might be ascertained by the effectiveness of the data matching the department is undertaking.

Then the report deals with detecting people who are receiving incorrect payments, as a secondary matter. Verifying the accuracy of incomes declared is shown as being of even lesser importance, and the final matter is the detection of fictitious or assumed identities.

I think it is important to recognise that, because the department has produced some tables. In the appendices that I find particularly interesting—on page 81, at table 5—was the direct cost-benefit summary. What one sees there is that there is a persistent view that there is going to be a very high level of direct cost-benefit. Looking at the net benefit figure for 1993-94, the government's view was that it was going to be $63 million—still nowhere near the $300 million originally held out. What is interesting is the way in which that tails off. In 1994-95, the department thinks, it is going to drop to $38 million; in 1995-96, it will drop to $23 million. I do not know how these figures were achieved, but one must consider them somewhat random, because they are the same for 1996-97 and 1997-98—a mere $21,183,000 for each of those years.

What one sees is an effort to develop a cost-benefit summary which includes savings associated with voluntary compliance, and that comes out in table 6. Of course, what one sees there in the projections is an estimate that voluntary compliance is yielding something in the order of $42 million worth of savings, and that it will go up next year, such that we will still get approximately the same total amount of savings even though the direct cost is falling. The voluntary savings will go up to $71 million and, in the following year, to $83 million. Again, in 1996-97 and 1997-98, it is going to go to a similar figure for each year: there, it is rounded off to $90 million. So the government seems to have set out the rather imaginative view that there can be direct cost-benefit analysis—including voluntary compliance, which is going to yield somewhere between $120 million and $130 million a year, ad infinitum—and has rounded off some of the future projections to achieve it.

My problem is that I do not know how accurate those matters are. I read with great interest the way in which the department tried to deal with the criticism developed by the Auditor-General. In chapter 4, there is an assessment of the program. It deals with the Australian National Audit Office efficiency audit. As one goes through each of the recommendations that the audit office made, one finds a series of fairly esoteric arguments in which the department is taking issue with the audit office. Page 29 indicates that they are having `discussions'. But, at the bottom of page 29, the report states that the department has:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . disagreed that recording individual project costs would help identify effective projects.
What one finds is a series of conflicts—almost interdepartmental conflicts—between the specialists of the Department of Social Security and the Auditor-General.

PARA.TAB: I am not able to resolve these matters. It is clear that the Department of Social Security is using this report for taking issue with the Auditor-General, but there are no further Auditor-General's comments. I want to conclude my remarks in relation to this matter by noting that there was a report of the Auditor-General tabled yesterday and that report did not deal with this matter, but it did reveal poor performance in relation to others. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to rise to speak on this report of the Department of Social Security on the data-matching program because I thought the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock), in speaking here in the Main Committee, was actually going to do so in praise of what has been achieved by the Department of Social Security.

PARA.TAB: We have references back to 1984 and decisions that were made then. I must repeat for the record that the Department of Social Security's legislation is very much a people's legislation that cannot be set in concrete. It must continue to evolve and it must particularly take on board the concerns of the electorate at large regarding the disposing and expenditure of taxpayers' money.

There are a number of points made by the honourable member for Berowra. I would not like to think that any person reading the Hansard and not reading the complete data-matching program report would in any way at all think that those remarks were critical in the report. For example, the honourable member referred in the closing part of his speech to the bottom of page 29. I would like to bring people's notice to the very beginning when the Australian National Audit Office report indicated that the program is a valuable compliance and control technique which addresses areas of risk and which other review activities do not cover as effectively.

It is noted that the savings originally estimated may not have been achieved. We acknowledge that, but the Audit Office has confirmed that the department and the data-matching agency effectively—and I emphasise that, effectively—fulfil their obligations under the act and certainly under the privacy guidelines. I think that is a very important point to make because the department as a whole, since data-matching came into being with a change to the act of 1991, has very effectively brought about changes to the whole structure of how we monitor and perhaps control fraud within the department itself.

The data-matching program itself is designed to correct incorrect payments of income support. Of course, that is done by the checking of the integrity of the information that people provide to us about their identity. They provide the information on identity but they also provide information as required on income. The program itself is also used to identify those in receipt of basic family payment who have declared income to the Australian Taxation Office and who may be eligible for extra assistance in the form of additional family payment.

I might add that that cross-checking is only done with the concurrence of the person. In all but exceptional cases our Department of Social Security does contact those who are the subject of an apparent match, to verify information before they even contact a third party. I think that is important to note. It is also important to note that there have been occasions where those people who are perhaps entitled to family payments have not been receiving them, and we have been able to detect that as well.

The honourable member for Berowra made mention of some of the tables in the report, and I think it is pertinent to look at those. In 1993-94 five data-matching cycles were conducted and 61,636 reviews of entitlement produced substantial direct savings of $79.8 million. I do not think that is small bickies. A lot of taxpayers' money has been saved because of the action we have taken.

Furthermore, there is evidence that the level of voluntary compliance with the social security system has increased since the department began collecting tax file numbers and using them in the data-matching program. In one of our reports we have the estimate that on an ongoing basis an annual amount of about $120 million will be saved through people voluntarily surrendering their payments. In other words, they are aware of the action the Department of Social Security now takes. They are being given a backup of assurance that, if the information that is being provided is in any way incorrect, through data matching we have means at our disposal with which to pick that up. All in all, Mr Deputy Speaker, the report covers very succinctly those particular cases.

Some people say, `Why have we ever had a need of it? Are you saying that people either fraudulently or incorrectly are receiving these payments?' No system we have which actually administers taxpayer's dollars, whether it be the Department of Social Security's system or any other system, can always be 100 per cent perfect. We try continually in the department to monitor the programs that we have in place, but most particularly we try to be observant of changes both in technology and in the receipt of information which can be utilised to make sure that that protection to the taxpayer's dollar is there at all times. The honest people who receive the payment—the honest people who make up 99.9 per cent of the population who are receiving payments for the Department of Social Security—appreciate this. Time and time again we have had both individuals and bodies praise the Department of Social Security for the very sure way in which it has administered this particular data-matching program. Most particularly, there is praise for the very caring way in which the department's officers have gone about their role; and certainly, in the requiring of information and evidence, there is praise for the way it has been treated privately. Most particularly, there is praise for the savings that have been afforded, as this report indicates.

I thank the honourable member for Berowra for his statement that he certainly appreciates sections of the report and what has been achieved by them; but I think that rather than being critical just of certain lines and taking certain paragraphs out of context, which he has a tendency to do, what is required is the taking on board of the whole report. We must not just summarise a line in the report. It is far more beneficial to the appreciation both of the reader and of any person who may be listening to this debate to take on board the whole report. It is very easy for all of us to take a line or a sentence and then misconstrue the meaning, whether it is the auditor's meaning or the department's meaning.

In all fairness, the report itself, as tabled in the House, is a very fair report. Certainly, at no time have we ever said that we are 100 per cent perfect, but we are acknowledging the work that has been achieved. We have brought to light, as required, the achievements within the department on the processes of the matching as far as it affects Social Security.

We compare the clients' identity details with the records of a number of other Commonwealth and state bodies and private insurers. We do that mainly to identify income changes or even changes in circumstances which clients may not have declared. I am not saying that at all times they do it purposely; sometimes inadvertently a client may not put in all the particulars required. That is where the data-matching process comes into being. It is a very good backup for the Department of Social Security. Most particularly, it provides the department with the means to monitor at all times, and respond to those numerous questions that are always being asked by the population at large.

Are we sure that our taxpayers' dollars are being spent wisely? We have very much a needs based payment system. Because of the safety net that the Department of Social Security has, there is a need to make sure that we are giving those payments to those who are in need and to those who require them. That is what this, as part of our program of implementation, is all about. I certainly appreciate the report being brought before the Main Committee, because it enables us to put forward those extra facts that may not be written into the report.

Debate resumed from 23 March 1994, on motion by Mr Beazley:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, perhaps I may just advert to the matter that has just been concluded indirectly by saying that I hope that we may see a further Auditor-General's report on the matters that are at issue. I think that is particularly important if we are able to make sensible conclusions on the disparities that I raised. I turn particularly to the issue of the paper that we are now discussing, which is the Performance standards 1993-94 for the Department of Social Security. Since that document was tabled and discussion was adjourned I have seen the proposals for 1994-95 performance standards, and in my comments I will draw attention to both documents.

PARA.TAB: I want to make a number of comments on this because the issue of performance in the Department of Social Security is of the utmost importance. The timeliness with which people receive their payments is a matter for which one ought not only have targets—which these papers give us—but also actual performance. I am a touch surprised. There were some changes between 1993 and 1994, and one of the interesting changes was that we had for the disability support pension in 1993-94 a target to pay, within 56 days of the claim, only 60 per cent of the claims made. In the new document that has been raised to 70 per cent.

Consider the importance of this particular payment: it is, in effect, the payment made to severely handicapped people. When you consider that we have something of the order of 400,000 people receiving the disability support pension, given this target, it would suggest that in 1993-94, if they had all been coming onto the pension at that time—and perhaps they were not, but if they all had been—somewhere in the order of 160,000 people would have had to wait longer than 56 days before receiving their first payment. That is an incredible degree of hardship that people who are, prima facie, in very difficult circumstances are going to have to face.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a lot more testing required.

—There is significant testing, and it involves other government departments, and I would imagine that that is probably the reason that it takes so long—because, no doubt, one has to get advice from medical officers, and the Commonwealth medical officers are involved—but it does reflect upon the performance, and that is what we are looking at. In relation to the child disability allowance, which is a similar matter, 56 days is the time thought reasonable for considering claims, so it is quite a long time—almost two months—and 80 per cent is the target.

PARA.TAB: When one starts to measure these claims against performance—and one has to go to some other documents that are produced in the budget to look at performance issues—it is very interesting that, in relation to the child disability allowance, the report commenting on 1992-93 had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The timeliness standard for the Child Disability Allowance (CDA) is to pay claims within 56 days of lodgement. The target for meeting this standard is that 80 per cent of claims paid are paid inside the standard. Collection of data against this standard only commenced in September 1992.
In the 1992-93 financial year performance result (since September 1992) for CDA is that 62 per cent of claims paid were paid inside standard

So the government is saying that even though they had a target of 80 per cent, they were only able to achieve payment of 62 per cent of the claims within that time. The comments I want to make here relate not only to the importance of meeting standards but also to satisfying the relevant criteria.

PARA.TAB: I am told that, in fact, in an effort to address performance, certain changes have occurred in relation to the way in which these matters are considered. It is interesting that, when one looks at the program performance statements of the department, one finds that the largest area of health that is considered for qualifying for the disability allowance is, in fact, asthma.

Asthma can be a particularly serious disability. I have known very close family friends who have lost loved ones through asthma. It can be quite tragic, but the very nature of it means that it can also be very mild. Some of it comes and goes. When my daughter was swimming actively she was seen as an asthma sufferer and was given one of those little squeezer things. There is no doubt that for a point in time she was a mild sufferer of asthma, but, if we were recipients of social security payments, given the nature of the condition that she had, there is no way that the child disability allowance would have been payable.

I am told, in order to get the performance up, what has been happening is that a lot of the determinations in relation to eligibility for this payment are being made by social workers. In other words, if people refer the claimant to the Commonwealth medical officer it reflects upon their performance. When people are worried about their performance, they do not send the person on for assessment—the social worker makes the claim. It is interesting that the claims for asthma, where the judgment can be so esoteric, have been rising rapidly, as can be seen in the performance statements which the government produces. In relation to performance standards, I am concerned that the government tells us in the paper that is tabled what the target is, but to find out what the performance is we have to hunt in other documents.

TALK.START.PARA: —You only have to ask.

—I welcome the offer of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security. I would like to see it taken out in relation to each of these matters. I would also like to know why we are seeing certain changes occurring. What I found particularly interesting in the 1993-94 program statement on page 2, under `Review and Appeals', is that there was a national standard when matters were raised between authorised review officers. The statement says:

SPEECH.PARA: The National Standard
14 days to finalise (where the client left without income) after request lodged at Regional Office—95%
14 days to finalise after request lodged at Regional Office (all types of review) . . .

And there the objective is only to achieve it by 40 per cent. When I look at the 1994-95 performance standards, and I look at that particular table, I find that there has been a change. They now leave out altogether the area in which the target is low at 40 per cent. So people now cannot find out. There is no target for 14 days to finalise after request lodged at regional office for all types of reviews. There has been a continuation with the other national standards where people are left without adequate means of support, but, in relation to the 14 days to finalise, that information is no longer provided.

PARA.TAB: Lest I run out of time again, I will move quickly to the concern I have as to what happened over the Christmas period in relation to performance. One of the concerns I have is that these tables with targets suggest a very high level of performance by the Department of Social Security, but over the Christmas period I was really quite concerned when it became apparent that the Department of Social Security was telling people that it was too busy to be able to process claims. We had something of the order of 42,000 families that the department acknowledged had been affected.

I have copies of the letters that were sent out by people in the department at that time. What they did was send out letters which told people that they were, in effect, unable to process their review forms. A letter about family payments that I have before me, dated 19 December, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear . . .
I am writing to you about your Family Payment.
We cannot pay you Additional Family Payment and Family Payment any more.

This is because, although you have returned the review form we sent you, we have been unable to process it yet. We will process your review form as soon as possible and you will be paid any arrears owing to you. If you have not received your payment by 19 January 1995 or you want to know more about your Family Payment, please phone the number at the top of this letter after that date.
This has been decided under section(s) 880 of the Social Security Act 1991.

I find it absolutely abhorrent that, at a time like Christmas when people had additional commitments they would ordinarily be expected to meet, the department was unable to process information that it had sought and received, and that it simply took people off benefits. It said, `If you are still entitled, we will put you back'—at some later date. But at the very time when hardship was most likely to have been endured, people were left without funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is old news. It's three months ago.

—The Parliamentary Secretary says it is old news. I say this to the Parliamentary Secretary: this is the first opportunity, when we are looking at the department's performance, that members get to raise these matters. And I also point out that there were no announcements by the Department of Social Security that made this news at the time when it occurred. The person who had to raise it was me, as the shadow minister!

PARA.TAB: The fact that 42,000 families had been taken off payments would not have been known except that, in response to my press release, the government had to come clean. That is the situation. It is quite indefensible that it occurred, and it reflects very poorly upon the department, and on the government's administration of the department, that that could happen.

You see, the department was out on a massive recruiting drive over the last few years. The department has record numbers of staff—something of the order of 21,000 people. We are at a time when the government tells us that unemployment is coming off. In that situation, it could have been expected that people who would otherwise have been paying unemployment benefits would have been freed of those tasks and the government could have prioritised this activity, which was crucial to people's income support over the Christmas period, if it was really concerned about the issue.

Quite frankly, when the test came, the government was wanting. When the test was there, the government wanted to hide it; it did not want people to know. There were no press statements on it. I watch what the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) says. There were no statements by the minister on this matter. I asked the minister to come out and speak on it himself, at that time. And what did he do? He sent out the departmental officers to make the explanations. I regard it as a very poor standard of performance. We need to hear a lot more from the government, not only in terms of the standards that are set, but also in terms of the need for them to publish comprehensive details about the way in which they measure up against these performance standards. That is the information that is not available; it is effectively hidden.

The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mrs Crosio) says that I can come along and ask for it. To my way of thinking, it is not a matter that I should have to ask for; it is a matter on which the government ought to come clean and provide the information. If its performance is up to standard, I would be the first to congratulate the government on it. But when its performance is as wanting as it has been in this area, it ought to expect and anticipate that these matters will be raised in the parliament at the first available opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to contribute to the debate on this motion to take note of the Department of Social Security performance standards 1994 report and to follow on from the comments made by my colleague, the member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock). As a member of the Procedure Committee, I want to start by making the observation that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) ought to be here for this particular debate. In saying that, I make no personal reflection on the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mrs Crosio), who is present and who I know is a hard worker.

PARA.TAB: In the creation of the Main Committee as the second chamber of the House of Representatives, we on the opposition side were at great pains to point out that unless this chamber were treated seriously it would become a second-class debating forum in which whatever occurs is treated as second best, or of less significance than a debate occurring in the House itself.

It behoves the minister to come into the Main Committee. Perhaps he would find it a little bit degrading to come here and listen to this debate and take note of the comments being made by members participating, because he would then learn of the immense difficulties being experienced by Australians all round the country in relation to social security entitlements and the departmental service. He would also learn of some of the comments and complaints of his own staff, who, in the case of the Joondalup Department of Social Security office, are working under enormous strains.

From time to time one listens to the minister in the chamber, when he is asked a dorothy dix question and makes some lengthy dissertation on the social progress being made, or talks of the social justice of this government. He would no doubt be mindful of the conference that is taking place in Copenhagen in relation to social justice. But I imagine also that he would be very defensive if we were to point out, as we have done from time to time—I know the honourable member for Berowra has done so—that under this government we have seen an ever-widening gap between the rich and the poor in our community, a community that, when I arrived here in 1971, was renowned for its fairness and equality.

When I first arrived in this country there was little difference in real terms between the salaries, or the standard of living, of people who were in middle management or in responsible positions, and those people who had physical jobs or service jobs. Unfortunately we have seen, in particular since 1983, following the election of the federal Labor governments under Hawke and Keating, an ever-widening gap between the poor and the rich in Australia, to such an extent that there are now about 8 1/2 million people in this nation who depend, either in full or in part, on some form of income from the Commonwealth government. In a modern, vibrant democracy, with all the resources that we have available to our community, that is obviously a national disgrace.

The grinding edge of this particular problem is at the front counter of the DSS office. In my electorate—which has within it the fast growing region of the city of Wanneroo—12,000 new people arrive each year. This is an increase of approximately 10 per cent each year. As a consequence, there is an enormous strain on the services that are available within our region.

We have within the electorate of Moore the highest concentration of children up to the age of five. We also have one of the highest concentrations of children between the ages of five and 15. Significantly—or ironically I suppose—we also have the greatest concentration of four-bedroom homes, but I do not think that has got as much to do with prosperity, as it has with the number of children being raised in the region.

Consequently, in my electorate there is a great demand for services from the Commonwealth government and, in particular, from the Department of Social Security. At various times I have become aware of significant problems with the office at Joondalup. The problems are those referred to by the member for Berowra: the difficulty in the interpretation of rulings and particular criteria, and also the sheer increase in demand.

I recently became aware that people were being referred to me by staff at the department's Joondalup office. Because their cases were difficult, they were being told, `You really ought to go and see your local MP.' In my constituency office, we take a great deal of pride in providing a good service to our constituents but I might say that this is placing quite a bit of strain on my office. We are basically having to deal with the by-product of the enormous strain on the Department of Social Security's office at Joondalup.

I would particularly like to commend the staff at the Joondalup office of the Department of Social Security. They are working under extraordinary pressure. All I can do on their behalf is ask that the parliamentary secretary and, through her, the minister look immediately at the workload that is being undertaken by officers at the Joondalup office to see whether there is some way to alleviate this additional strain so that the office can provide a better standard of service to my constituents.

I also raised the issue of the teleservice centre with the parliamentary secretary. In fairness to her—and I meant no personal reflection when I mentioned the minister—I must say that she has been prompt in responding to my queries and I appreciate that on behalf of my constituents. I complained to her about the teleservice centre arrangements. This is another issue that, as she would know from her own constituents, causes almost insufferable frustration on the part of people who are trying to get though on the help line to get basic information. Because of the rapid changes in circumstances in the Department of Social Security, or because of changes in the various legislation within the department's jurisdiction, people require—as much as possible—instant service so that they can take full advantage of their entitlements, even when changes occur sometimes in circumstances that may well militate against the individual constituent.

I also point out that, with respect to the office at Joondalup, I have had complaints from people who have recently had to wait up to 1 1/2 hours to get attention there. I think that is something that I would like to see remedied as quickly as possible. Again, I make no reflection on the staff at the office. I know many of them personally and I have a great deal of respect for them. I know that they are operating in difficult circumstances and that they are endeavouring to do their best on behalf of my constituents. Nonetheless, I would like to see the situation improved as quickly as possible.

I would like to touch on a matter that relates to performance. It is not quite in the area of direct service to clients, as they are euphemistically called; basically, they are recipients or applicants. I do not like the term `clients'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The correct title now is `customer' and I don't like that either.

—So we are now calling them customers. I think we would be better off if we called them citizens or people, rather than calling them by some euphemistic phrase which covers the fact that they are unfortunately placed in the situation where they need to have social security payments to help them get by.

PARA.TAB: I now go to an issue that arose in 1991, which is long before the time of the parliamentary secretary's tenure as the parliamentary secretary. I want to address a matter that continues to represent a gross injustice for another group of people in my electorate. They have suffered as a consequence of joint exercises conducted by the department, the DSS, the Australian Taxation Office and the Australian Federal Police. In 1991, some so-called `visits'—they were actually raids—were made to some strawberry growers in my electorate. Only a small number were visited, or raided, but as a consequence of those visits or raids many of their workers fled.

I do not want to go into great detail about why these people may have felt alarmed or intimidated by the presence of police officers and other officers in the early hours of the morning at the strawberry fields in my electorate. All I can say is that many of those workers came from countries that have long suffered under Communist regimes. I believe they have a natural instinct to feel afraid or worried in the presence of authoritarian or authoritative officers.

As a consequence of these raids, my constituents' strawberry picking period—the peak period which is in the latter part of the year, in the summer—was severely impeded by the then consequent lack of labour. In some instances, constituents lost up to $1.5 million—in particular, one particular constituent who is the largest strawberry grower in Western Australia. He suffered the most and he has ever since been trying to exact justice as a consequence of these losses.

Let me point out some of the things that this gentleman has had to do. I have spoken on a number of occasions here in relation to this matter. I have made representations to the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) and to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Mr Elliott). I have spoken in previous debates on data-matching programs and I have made interminable representations. One particular thing I did was to take out freedom of information requests in relation to the Australian Taxation Office relating to meetings that had been held—I will show members where this is relevant—with officers of the Australian Taxation Office, the Department of Social Security and the Australian Federal Police prior to these raids taking place. To my great consternation, when seeking these freedom of information documents, we could find no evidence of the notes of the meetings that had taken place with the officers of the three bodies. In particular, these notes would have related to or reflected upon the actual complaints—

TALK.START.PARA: —A long, long bow.

—No, it is not a long bow. These people had losses of $1.5 million in one particular case. What I am saying is this: in this particular instance, officers of the three bodies have failed to keep notes of meetings in which allegations against my constituents—or, for that matter, others—have allegedly been raised and discussed. That means that my constituent was unable to seek further information that would allow him to take legal action in order to get retribution for the enormous financial losses he has suffered.

PARA.TAB: I implored the previous Minister for Social Security, the Hon. Neal Blewett, to look at this matter with a sympathetic view towards an ex gratia payment of compensation to those of my constituents who have suffered these losses. The reason I asked for this is, quite frankly, that they were entirely innocent parties. There has been no allegation of offences against them and no charges, nor has there been any suggestion of charges. Yet this situation was a consequence of this joint exercise.

I might add that the Department of Social Security strangely dropped out of the exercise at the last moment. My constituent had actually complained to the Department of Social Security prior to the raids taking place. The DSS officers dropped out of the exercise and only ATO and AFP officers were present at the time. Nonetheless, it was a joint exercise and I can only urge the parliamentary secretary to ask for that matter to be looked at again. I am only too happy to provide the particulars so that she may do that.

In conclusion, may I just urge, as I urged earlier, the parliamentary secretary—who I know is an efficient person—to make the necessary inquiries to ascertain what extra resources are required at Joondalup and to make sure the minister is aware of the grinding edge, as we said, of that new problem area we find with this unfortunate greater dependency of many Australians on social security payments. At the front counter where these performance standards are supposedly being measured people should have equal access to highly efficient service from the department's officers. In areas like Joondalup and Wanneroo where the growth is so phenomenal, those resources should be beefed up to the maximum to ensure that people do get equal access and fair access to the service.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not originally going to reply but a number of points have been made both by the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) and the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) so I feel it is necessary to reply.

PARA.TAB: I think I will start with what the honourable member for Moore has raised. I had to look again at the Main Committee's agenda. It is clearly marked as `Department of Social Security—Performance standards 1993-94'. He did use a very broad brush to bring in the concerns he had in 1991. It would be on the record that in the department we were not even publishing our standards until 1992. It does take a lot of understanding to see how what the member was talking about related to the actual report before the Main Committee.

A number of other points have been raised. Certainly, I will investigate them on his behalf. He has raised concerns, as a member rightfully should, over a particular office within his electorate. I do also take note of the teleservice centres. This is something that is continually being reviewed within the department. But I would put my comments on record as to why that review is constantly taking place in the teleservice centres. I agree with the honourable member about frustration arising when people cannot get on, and they get a busy signal. That is something that we are always bringing to notice.

At the same time, the idea of having a teleservice centre was first agreed to in 1992, and we then started erecting the centres around Australia. I believe that one of the things we must look at now, as we divide our areas up, is having a teleservice centre in every one of those areas and having area managers take more note of what is happening, particularly in relation to the distribution of the labour force in the areas at the time of need. But, at the same time, we must acknowledge that there are something like 15 million calls expected to go through our teleservice centres this year.

Teleservice centres started as an idea to relieve the pressure on our counter staff. They have evolved to such an extent that I now feel sure that if people are an hour late in getting their age pension payments they are ringing up our teleservice centres. We are certainly looking at our voice review units, to see whether there is some way we can get an extra message on. We have changed the lines, as honourable members are aware. We have given more direct lines to pensioners. We are also continually looking at the available technology and at the possibility that we have not got enough Telecom lines coming through in certain areas. We are continually monitoring the situation.

We are aware of the concern of the constituents, because that is continually being raised in the department and by all members of the House. It is certainly something we are doing our best to overcome. We acknowledge that there is a problem there. But we also must acknowledge that if complaints come to our offices—there are something like 147 members of parliament—there are perhaps two or three of them, while there are up to 300,000 or 400,000 calls going through, at that one particular time, around Australia. So the number of complaints coming in is not large in comparison to the number of calls going through the centres. Nevertheless, they are a cause of concern and, if they are a cause of concern, they need investigation. We certainly need solutions to the problems that have been experienced.

The other areas I would like to touch on include standards. I emphasise the fact that the standards were actually put into place for publication to make sure that they provided a broad approach to improving client services for our general staff. The honourable member for Berowra touched on a number of areas that were causing concern to him, such as the disability support pension. Sure, we had originally set a target, but I think I must go on to the new figures here. The original target we set for 1993-94 was something like 60 per cent of payments within 56 days of claim. We know that that 1993-94 year reached 78 per cent.

As the honourable member well knows, disability payments take a long time because they involve not only the checking of the relevant departments but also the requirement for proper health checks and ensuring that those health checks comply with what is required. Anyone can walk in with a doctor's certificate and say, `My doctor says I have got a, b and c. Therefore, I have got to go on a disability support pension.' It requires a lot more than that. It requires a very exacting decision making process, which needs to be put into place and continually updated. Certainly, it requires further medicals, and it requires medicals throughout particular time frames suitable for particular people going through the actual process.

The honourable member for Berowra raised the subject of asthma. I would like to see the records showing where social workers are approving disability support pension for asthmatic patients. I find that quite extraordinary.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have access to them.

—I will certainly have a review of that, and I will certainly raise that with the minister. As the member for Berowra well knows, even with disability support pension, if it is refused you have the right to a full appeal before an independent tribunal—
—You don't appeal against a grant.

—No. The honourable member mentioned the actual disability pensions that were being made available by social workers in regard to people suffering from asthma. I found it was rather disconcerting to have that there.

PARA.TAB: The other issue which the member for Berowra raised, which I also found a little bit disconcerting, was the child disability allowance. Again, we had set a target—something like 80 per cent—which we would have liked to have achieved within the time frame that we had set ourselves, and we did not get to that. We did get to only 70 per cent. Again, that was because there is caring approach required in order to grant a disability support pension to a child, and there is a lot of investigation required. I would not like to think, at any time, that because we have rushed through decision making some person is being denied access to a pension. But, at the same time, we must make sure that performance standards are in place, and that the payments are made accordingly.

The Department of Social Security has published a series of client service performance standards only since 1992. It is good to have that on record and also to have on record the reason that the department is doing this. It is doing it because of this broad approach to improve our client service. The standards themselves need to be understood to appreciate why the publication is as it is. The standards are set mainly because we want to look at the timeliness and the accuracy of the decisions made to pay those particular claims, whatever they may be.

We also want to continue a review on the timeliness of processing the inquiries that come through, including our telephone inquiries and office inquiries, the provision of interpreter services and ministerial correspondence. All these things are part of standards which the department sets for itself. We also want to make sure that we cover the timeliness of answers to parliamentary questions. We look at processing our reviews and appeals—that is, how authorised review officers of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal are handling them and how quickly they are dealing with them. This is all part of a standard process that we are virtually policing ourselves in the department so that we can say, `We have reached our goal now; we are doing very well.' We believe, with reviews and technology, that perhaps we can do a little bit better.

Of course, one of the important things is the timeliness of overpayment raising and even prosecution referral. That is why it is important to understand that standards are not just a wish list; standards and performance standards are not just there as a figure. I sometimes wonder whether we set too high a standard, particularly in the teleservice centre. I have raised this with the department and it is public knowledge. I think we need to review continually the causes of interruptions and programs and identify what is causing a particular downgrading in that standard expectation.

The honourable member for Berowra also raised that particular correspondence. I can assure him that he is not the only one who raised it. A number of us, including me, have raised it. Our constituents who have had this type of letter have come to us. I tell them that we look continually at review processes and at how those letters are put together. It is inexcusable; I am not defending it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Inexcusable.

—Inexcusable. I am not defending it. My personal view is that no correspondence should go out to a constituent in a case like that. How many pieces of correspondence does the Department of Social Security deal with? There are something like 4 1/2 million payments of one form or another. Every time a review process is required or legislation is changed, our clients need to be notified. Correspondence is dealt with on a daily basis, let alone a weekly or a yearly basis. We can all pull out a page or a letter that one of our constituents has brought to us that can be viewed with concern. We are well aware of the particular matter that the honourable member for Berowra raised. We did not need him to raise it. It is old news; it occurred just before Christmas and it is certainly something that we are very concerned about. I give him a similar example when another review was raised in our teleservice centres. It was absolutely chock-a-block all over Australia. It occurred because the ANZ bank delayed payment of the pension at that particular time and it caused a problem, certainly a major hiccup, within our teleservice centres.

PARA.TAB: When we are critical of what our department does, we must also take on board the number of people we have to deal with; the number of people who are employed both at the counter face and through the teleservice centres; and, most particularly, the nature of the work involved in this area. While we should not have mistakes, none of us are perfect. Nor is the legislation perfect and never to be changed. I repeatedly say in Department of Social Security debates that the legislation should never be set in concrete. We should evolve: we should continue to change to meet people's needs. The same thing applies with correspondence and the way we deal with our constituents and clients. If we have a mistake, we must acknowledge that mistake, rectify it and, most importantly, make sure that that type of mistake does not occur again in the future. That is what standards are all about. In 12 months time, when we again talk about the standards that we have started to publish since 1992, if we have incurred the same problems in those same areas, we will certainly need to take on board why that has occurred.

I give assurance that I am continually aware of that. I know my minister is, because he at all times is very mindful of the concerns of the constituents coming to him and the types of changes and the long-term goals which we set the department for the department's people to meet and achieve. It is very much a people's department; it is very much people we are dealing with at all levels. Most particularly, the standards we set are to make sure that our department and staff meet those guidelines and meet the delivery of services to the people we are most concerned about.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 18 October 1994, on motion by Mr Beazley:
That the House take note of the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak on the data-matching program and the report from the Department of Employment, Education and Training which has been supplied to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) explaining what the position is at this stage with data processing in that department. It is a pretty important area, which we need to highlight. I understand the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) was going to speak on it earlier but obviously his other commitments have kept him from doing so. So I will just take a few moments of the Committee's time this morning to make a few points about it.

PARA.TAB: One of the important things to note about the whole data-matching program is that it does not function just to pick up students who are receiving payments they are not entitled to but also looks at other ways to stop the rorting of the system. That is pretty important, as is the fact that it also serves to identify students who may be entitled to other payments. Quite often we hear that students who are looking for assistance, and rightly should have that assistance, do not know what their benefits or entitlements are. It is an important aspect of the program that they are well aware of those. The program is a powerful tool for the department to use to pursue the entitled level of financial assistance to those students.

However, the primary function of the data-matching program remains to detect incorrect payments. That is something that, from the public accountability point of view, I think we are all aware of. Before the 1990-91 budget, data matching for cost recovery purposes was costly, time consuming and quite inefficient. That budget introduced the requirement for most people claiming government assistance to provide tax file numbers as a prerequisite to payment, which has been an important part of the data-matching program.

Increased computerised matching of data held by various Commonwealth agencies has been of assistance here as well. It is not only the Department of Employment, Education and Training that uses the data-matching program. The Department of Social Security, the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the Department of Housing and Regional Development, and the Australian Taxation Office itself are very interested in that area.

It is important to look at some of the benefits that have come from the data-matching program, as well as the costs associated with that and the cost recovery program. The cost since 1981 has been $1.8 million; in 1993-94 it was $630,650. Of the 1993-94 cost, 83 per cent was for computer support and staff salaries. When we compare that with the savings that have been identified by the program since April 1981, it is interesting to note that $12,338,238 has been saved. When the cost factor associated with that saving is deducted, the overall net profit is $10,512,075. There are some other significant benefits. There was $102,685 identified as underpayments since 1981. That just concerns those people who have been underpaid who need that assistance.

As well as the financial savings benefits, an efficient data-matching program provides a significant deterrent to people who would try to claim assistance for which they are ineligible. It acts as an incentive to tell the truth, which is a real plus for the public purse. The department and the government actively publish the program and publicise it, which is very important. The department is of the opinion that this has led to a significant increase in the degree of voluntary compliance among clients, particularly in the case of changing circumstances that may affect their eligibility for student assistance.

While this is not the appropriate time to debate the advantages or shortcomings of the student assistance scheme, it should be appreciated that an efficient data-matching program that catches out those who are claiming undeserved assistance frees up the total pool of financial resources for those worthy students who are deserving of additional assistance. As I mentioned before, it is important that those students actually receive the assistance they need.

The argument can always be put for increasing the level of student assistance. Having four sons of my own in that field, I am reminded of it pretty regularly, particularly of course in the pursuit of our national drive for increased access to, and funding for, higher education. In states such as my own state of Queensland there is a shortage, which we keep reminding the minister about. The fact that he is addressing the problem is certainly welcomed by most Queenslanders and acknowledged by the Queensland government. However, we acknowledge that, as with everything else, the provision of funds is subject to budgetary constraints. Nevertheless, the minister has certainly made some positive statements in that area. The more money that can be provided through other means such as identifying undeserved overpayments, the more students will benefit, and we will have a pool of funds from which those in the greatest need can obtain assistance. Of course, on the other side of the coin, the application process for student assistance is large and very complex. From my family's point of view, when one of my sons went to university in Sydney one of the first things that happened was that he was given an Austudy form to fill out. As he filled it out I expressed my doubts that be would be entitled to Austudy in view of his age and my income. Sure enough, he has been through the process, is not eligible for it and obviously does not get it. I just thought it was a waste of time his going through the exercise.

We could probably find a simpler way to identify whether people are eligible—some sort of ready-reckoner for applicants to use to describe themselves—rather than have them go through the whole process and waste the time of the department when clearly there are students who are not eligible who probably could have ticked a few boxes and concluded they were not eligible for whatever reasons. That is something I would like the department to look at at some time.

It does not really relate too much to the data-matching program but I wanted to make the point that some of those forms are somewhat daunting for people to fill out as well, and it would not be surprising to discover that, because of the forms, many students would not claim all the assistance they are entitled to. It is important that those who need the assistance are encouraged to apply for it.

I welcome the data-matching program's ability to identify those underpayments as a significant social justice measure but we need to make sure we have that right balance. It helps those most in need, which is important to the government and to all members of the parliament.

Such a system would benefit disadvantaged minority groups in our community. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are particularly important as far as education is concerned, and it is important that they know what is available for them and that they are encouraged to apply as well. Students from non-English speaking backgrounds also run into some difficulties from time to time, as do migrants and others from groups whose social position may have hindered them or anyone in their family from attending higher education. The whole system, at least at the outset, might appear to be something of a mystery to some of these groups, and they need to know that they should apply for assistance.

People who really need the added assistance to help them improve their position and opportunities must be encouraged to do so. Many people may take such opportunities for granted but no-one on this side of the House takes access to higher education for granted, given that we had to fight for so long for it. Everyone in this House would be pleased to see the number of students who are going on to higher education now. With the number of young people finishing high school—nearly 80 per cent of secondary students—and attending some form of higher education, keeping tabs on them all would be impossible without an effective data-matching program. Using the new technologies to advance processes is extremely important, and in some areas governments need to be able to change how the technologies are used, for the benefit of all departments.

The privacy question, of course, is something that we always need to be conscious of, to ensure that the Big Brother allegations are not highlighted and pushed too much. The Privacy Commissioner's office, of course, has conducted regular inspections of the program, and it has been important in ensuring that people do not feel intimidated in any way. I understand that the latest inspection was in 1993-94, when the Privacy Commissioner's office actually visited several of the data-matching programs around the country, and it is good that it goes out and looks at ensuring that privacy provisions are being maintained.

I do not want to take too much of the time of the committee, but I wish to make a few points in relation to this paper, and emphasise a few points about the benefits of data matching. Not only in DEET, but also in all the other departments, it is a good initiative and one which we should take the opportunity to advance, while at the same time, of course, ensuring that the individual's privacy is always respected. The main thing in this particular area is to ensure that students who need assistance actually receive that assistance.
